What‚Äôs your favorite and most proven slicer software to use? I‚Äôm currently using a mixture of Creality Print, Bambu Studio, Cura, and Orca slicer for different printers but am looking to move to using only 1 slicer for all 6 printers.

(Creality K1C, Ender 3 S1, Ender 3 Pro, Kingroon KP3, Kingroon KP3S Pro S1, Flsun QQ-S Pro)

Personally, I was a long-time Cura user (migrated from Slic3r years ago) and just this summer switched to Orca. I intend to standardize on Orca, at least for a while.

I‚Äôve been using Cura for years. Back in 2016/2017, I would‚Äôve said Cura.
Now? Probably PrusaSlicer or a derivative.
Cura‚Äôs been getting worse, and in my opinion, Cura 15.04.06 (a version from 2015) is far superior in most ways to whatever version is out now.

Cura is what I started out using and worked pretty good for the most part, but sadly I had to start moving away from it because it didn‚Äôt have a profile for the Creality K1C and was a pain when trying to send prints directly to my sonic pad for my Ender 3 S1.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T12:32:59.209Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":112,"readers_count":111,"score":62.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470131,"topic_slug":"best-3d-printer-slicer-software","display_username":"Will C","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49328,"username":"char","name":"Chris Harrison","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/char/{size}/159140_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66211,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design"},"post_url":"/t/best-3d-printer-slicer-software/470131/9","custom_user_title":"3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417566,"name":"tkchan","username":"tkchan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ee59a6/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T13:46:29.944Z","cooked":"

Bambu studio/Orca are really an improved version of PrusaSlicer. I like the PrusaSlicer approach over Cura. But the Bambu Studio project/multi-plate approach to me is the best thing since slice bread. Now you can put everything (regardless of materials) you need all into 1 single file. You can group the items onto the same plate and then slice them together. I‚Äôm waiting for them to have a way to have each PLATE to have its own slicing profile (i.e. materials, nozzle, wall, support, etc - everything). That would complete the entire picture imo.

tkchan:

I‚Äôm waiting for them to have a way to have each PLATE to have its own slicing profile

You have a way to get that today by using what the slicer calls a printer profile to mean a printer&plate combination profile. (Instead of having a ‚ÄúBambu X1 0.2‚Äù profile, have ‚ÄúBambu X1 0.2 on Plate1‚Äù and ‚ÄúBambu X1 0.2 on Plate 2‚Äù profiles.)
